entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Finance integration and Use case with SAP Joule
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAP’s AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction types—Transactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analytical—that let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Here’s a structured view:

 SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

Deployment & Integration

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.

Feature Availability

  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: “Post vendor invoice” → transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customer’s upgrade cycle.

Customization & Extensibility

  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom coding—extensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.

Data Security & Residency

  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAP’s compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.

Upgrade & Innovation

  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades → Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive later—innovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

 Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

 Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud → Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud → Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supported—assuming you've got the right access and permissions.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically active—you must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Joule—but you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)

  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • There’s a planned strategy—possibly coming Q1 2025—to enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onward—activate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automatic—requires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Here’s how SAP Joule, SAP’s generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  • Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural language—imagine asking:

  • “Post a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.”
  • “Show me the status of PO invoice 10234.”
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Joule’s transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  • Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like “Display GL Account Balances,” you could simply ask:

  • “Where can I review G/L balances?”
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  • Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • “What’s the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?”
  • “Explain account determination for automatic postings.”
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.

Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • “Show me quarterly expense trends per cost center.”
  • “Which cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?”
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboards—leveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agents—autonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAP’s cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask “Where to view Cost Center Reports?”

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Joule’s capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

 Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    “Post an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.”
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-up—if payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    “What are the pending tasks for month-end close?”
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    “Show me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.”
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarter’s expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    “List journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.”
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    “What is today’s cash position?”
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    “Show me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.”
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    “Which cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?”
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

 How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill → “Generate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.”
  2. Create an Agent → “Monitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.”
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps → e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

 

 This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

 Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

 Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

 Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    “Post a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (“Create Vendor Invoice”).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms → Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup → available out-of-the-box.

 Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
     “Post a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.”
  • Joule Process:
    • Provide navigation → “Open FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)” or “Fiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.”
    • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

 Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Activation

Native, plug-and-play

Needs setup & integration

Invoice Posting

Joule executes directly in Fiori app

Joule suggests navigation, may require custom agent for automation

Data Validation

Standard rules auto-applied

Flexible, can embed custom compliance rules

User Effort

Minimal (voice/text → posted)

Moderate (confirmation in screen, extra steps if no custom agent)

Analytics

Immediate cash flow impact via SAC

Possible, but may need manual SAC integration

Customization

Limited (SAP-standard process)

Flexible (custom workflows, approvals, legacy integration)

Key Takeaway:

  • In Public Cloud, Joule = speed + simplicity → perfect for companies with standard finance processes.
  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility → better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

entry.title: Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Argentina with SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Understanding Index-Based Asset Revaluation

In Argentina, companies must periodically revalue their fixed assets to reflect inflationary changes. SAP's new feature automates this process, ensuring compliance with local regulations. By using the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, businesses can create and manage revaluation indices, which are then applied to asset master records for accurate valuation. When Depreciation Posting runs, the depreciation area will also post the revaluation by the Index registered (if it was assigned in the Fixed Asset Master Data)” in the Manage Monthly Closing Activities section.

Prerequisites

To be able to post a revaluation in a specific depreciation area, revaluation must be allowed in the depreciation area. SAP has defined for each depreciation area in the predefined configuration whether revaluation is allowed.

Step 1: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index

1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app.

2. Choose Create and specify the following details:

   - Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (independent of a specific company code)

   - Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly

4. Choose Continue.

5. On the Asset Revaluation Index page, in the Header section, specify values for all mandatory (*) fields, such as Index Description, Country/Region Key, and Currency

6. In the Index Items section, specify the index values such as the Valid To dates. The system automatically sets the Valid From dates.

7. Choose Create.

 At this point, the index’s lifecycle status is Created.

8. Choose Activate to make the index available for valuation views.

The index’s lifecycle status changes to Active.
For more information: see Maintain Asset Revaluation Index | SAP Help Portal

Step 2: Create Asset Master Record

You can use the Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425) to create and view asset master records and display asset values for each valuation.

You can create a new fixed asset from scratch, or you can use an existing fixed asset as a template. For more information on Manage Fixed Assets app (F3425), please refer to Manage Fixed Assets | SAP Help Portal

For more information on how to create asset master data, please refer to Creating Fixed Asset Master Data | SAP Help Portal

 Post Asset Acquisition

1. Open the Post Asset Acquisition app.

2. Choose Post > Post Acquisition > Acquisition (Net).

3. Specify all the mandatory values.

4. Choose Simulate to simulate the accounting posting.

5. Choose the expand icon to display all ledgers.
For more details on the Post Asset Acquisition app, see
Post Asset Acquisition - And Quantity Adjustment | SAP Help Portal

View Journal Entries

1. In the Post Asset Acquisition app, go to the Journal Entries tab, choose the document number of the journal entry, and then choose Display Journal Entries – New Version.

The system navigates to the Display Journal Entries app.

2. Go to the Line Items tab and choose T-Account View.

The accounting postings are displayed in the Display Journal Entries – In T-Account View app.

For more details, see Display Journal Entries – In T-Account View | SAP Help Portal

View Revaluations for the Fixed Asset

1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.

2. Search for and open the fixed asset that you created in Step 2.

3. On the Valuation tab, click the small right arrow to choose the depreciation area for which you want to view the revaluations.

4. Display the values by fiscal year or currency, as required.

This section acts as the "Fixed Asset Explorer", where the values are displayed at different times of the fiscal year.

5. Choose Explain Key Figures for information on the displayed values.

6. Go to the Journal Entries tab to view all documents posted in this depreciation area for this asset. These values can be displayed by fiscal year and currency.

7. Go to the Depreciation tab to view ordinary and revaluated depreciations for different fiscal periods.

Manage Monthly Closing Activities

1. Open the Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs app.

2. Choose Create.

3. Choose the job template Depreciation Posting Run and choose Step 2.

4. Set a schedule for the job to run and choose Step 3.5. To schedule and run the job, choose Schedule.

6. Choose the job and download the results.

View the depreciation values in the Manage Fixed Assets app.

For more details, see Schedule Asset Accounting Jobs | SAP Help Portal

Reporting: Reporting | SAP Help Portal

1. Use the Asset Accounting Overview app to access key information and KPIs within the Asset Accounting area, and gain insight into current trends.

2. Use the Asset Balances app to display balances of fixed assets according to various criteria, such as company code, depreciation area, segment, or profit center.

3. Use the Asset Transactions app to check and evaluate daily or monthly operations in Asset Accounting by listing asset transactions posted to the general ledger.

4. Use the Depreciation Lists app as a supplement to the profit and loss statement.

5. Use the Asset History Sheet app to display the asset history sheet, which shows value changes to the fixed asset balances in a fiscal year for a depreciation area.

Summary

The explained process of revaluation by indexes allows to cover the basic cases of the inflation adjustment process for fixed assets in Argentina means a simpler way. Additionally, the complex and non-common cases could be supported by extensibility.

entry.title: Re: Navigate to MD04 when click material number in monito...
entry.content:
Good day @Joey3 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Monitor Material Coverage - Net and Individual Segments Manage Material Coverage & Production Planning

To summarise, in public cloud edition, the monitor material coverage-net and individual segments app already provides standard navigation to the monitor material coverage app. This has replaced the former MD04 transaction. When you click the Material Number in the Net and Individual Segments list, the system automatically launches the Single Material view with the selected material, plant and MRP area will be prefilled.

Below is a description on how to navigate.

  • Open the Monitor Material Coverage,
  • Select Net and individual Segments,
  • Select an MRP standard definition and locate the Material number with a shortage.

  • Click the hyperlink of your choice as shown below. The system opens the Monitor Material Coverage app.
  • Verify that the material number, plant, and MRP are fields are automatically prefilled.
  • Thereafter you see the stock/replenishment list equivalent (formerly MD04).

 

If this navigation does not work on your system, please verify that both apps are included in your business role SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR_MRP and that you have the correct catalog assignments.

You do not require any additional configuration or enhancement because this is standard behaviour for the public cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI to Microsoft SharePoint Adapter Integration
entry.content:
I can answer myself to the above questions. They are all to be answered with yes, indeed!

The missing piece was the correct permission on the app registration. 

In the App Registration, we gave Listitems.SelectedOperations.Selected on Graph level and Sites.selected on SharePoint level. Both of type "application" (not "delegated"). That's more or less how I understand it from our Sharepoint admin. 

See more here: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/permissions-selected-overview?tabs=http

entry.title: Re: Migrating NowShortUrl of QR-codes from old company to...
entry.content:
Data API provides full read/write access to most of the data in a company, including NowShortUrlDTO. It is theoretically feasible with Data API to GET all NowShortUrlDTO objects from the old company A, and PUT them into the new company B.

However, there are two major caveats:

  • If the object reference of a NowShortUrlDTO is set to an object that belongs to company A, it will be invalid in company B, unless company B has been restored from a full data backup of company A.
  • The actual URLs of the the NowShortUrlDTO are permanently linked to the company they are originally created in. In practice, scanning such a QR-code will always direct the user to the Self-Service Portal of company A. This hard link cannot be changed via Data API (or any other available API).

entry.title: Enterprise Messaging in SAP: JMS vs Event Mesh vs AMQP Adapter
entry.content:
All three that is JMS, Event Mesh and AMQP adapters are widely used in SAP for different purposes. The common thing among all these three is that these three are asynchronous adapters.

Asynchronous means they send message without waiting for the response or they work independently. That means there is no need for both the sender and receiver to interact and work together.

Understanding the Basics 

Now let's just see the basics of each adapter and then dive deeper to the main part of the blog.

JMS 

JMS adapter stands for Java Message Service. It is used in cases where we need guaranteed message delivery by storing in queue (if needed) with CPI system. It is not specifically built for cloud-native or event driven architecture.

SAP Event Mesh

This is used in both cloud systems and event driven. It can be said cloud native as it is designed to run in cloud environments. Event driven as it is built around Pub-Sub (Publish-Subscribe) model. This is used widely for connecting outside the CPI system. This has many adapters like AMQP, MQTT(Message Queuing Protocol) and HTTP REST.

AMQP Adapter

AMQP stands for Advanced Event Mesh. It acts as a bridge between application and broker. Broker is nothing but an event broker like Solace. It is primarily an event driven architecture but can also be a part of cloud native architecture depending on the usage.

When to Use What?

Here’s how I usually decide between these options:

  • Go with JMS if...
    You’re working with java centric enterprise environment, need reliable messaging and on premise that in within the CI/CPI system.

  • Choose Event Mesh if...
    You’re working on cloud native or IOT applications, need real time event routing and need dynamic event distribution.

  • Use the AMQP Adapter if...
    You need to connect event brokers like any third-party broker system, interoperable messaging and control over message delivery, routing and reliability.

Real-World Scenarios

Let me share a couple of examples to put this into context:

  1. Legacy ECC System + JMS:
    In one project, wherein we needed a guaranteed message delivery, I used 2 I-flows and it was within the CPI system that is on premise system. For this JMS was the best adapter. We have to give the queue name, and select whether it's exclusive or non-exclusive.

  2. AMQP Adapter with Third-Party Systems:
    In another case, I needed to integrate SAP with a third-party logistics provider using Solace. So in this case this was the best suited as it is cloud supported. We have to give the username and password of solace adapter, give the credential name that we create in security material section.

So, the thing between choosing JMS, AMQP or Event Mesh depends on the situation and what is needed for a particular situation. So, with so many options being available on SAP, we have to make a wise choice to choose between the available adapters.

JMS vs Event Mesh vs AMQP Adapter

 

FeatureJMSEvent MeshAMQP Adapter
Best ForLegacy SAP (PI/PO, ECC)Cloud-native SAP (BTP, S/4)Hybrid SAP + external systems
ArchitectureTightly coupledLoosely coupled, event-drivenProtocol-based integration
ScalabilityLimitedHighDepends on external broker
Integration EffortLow (in legacy)Low (in BTP)Moderate
Real-Time SupportLimitedExcellentGood


Features JMS Event Mesh AMQP Adapter
*Best For Legacy SAP (PI/PO, ECC) Cloud-native SAP (BTP, S/4) Hybrid SAP + external systems.
*Architecture Tightly coupled Loosely coupled, event-driven Protocol-based integration.
*Scalability Limited High Depends on external broker.
*Integration Effort Low (in legacy) Low (in BTP) Moderate.
*Real-Time Support Limited Excellent Good.

Conclusion:

Picking the Right Messaging Tool for Your SAP Landscape
At the end of the day, choosing between JMS, Event Mesh, and the AMQP Adapter isn’t about which one is “better”—it’s about which one fits your current architecture, integration goals, and future roadmap.

If you're working with legacy SAP systems like PI/PO or ECC, JMS is still a solid choice. It’s stable, well-supported, and gets the job done in tightly coupled environments.

But if you're moving toward SAP BTP or building event-driven, cloud-native applications, Event Mesh is the way forward. It’s built for scale, flexibility, and real-time responsiveness—exactly what modern enterprise landscapes need.

And when you’re dealing with external systems—whether it’s a logistics partner using RabbitMQ or a cloud service on Azure—AMQP Adapter gives you the protocol-level integration you need without compromising on standards or reliability.

So, my advice? Start with your architecture and business needs, then choose the messaging tool that aligns best. And remember—these tools aren’t mutually exclusive. In many real-world SAP landscapes, you’ll find all three working together to keep data flowing smoothly across systems.

So, it's not just creating an I-flow and using whichever we feel better. It's about choosing the best among the available options and that which is practical for the application for which we are using a particular adapter. We have to choose the one with better efficiency. SAP has provided us with so many options, we have to choose the best one and it's important.

entry.title: Strengthening Security on SAP BTP Neo Environment with DigiCert Global Root G3
entry.content:
At SAP, keeping your data and applications secure is always a top priority.
To further strengthen the security of the SAP BTP Neo environment, we are migrating to the “DigiCert Global Root G3” Public Key Infrastructure (PKI). This update ensures long-term trust, improved encryption, and compliance with the latest international security standards.

Do You Need to Do Anything

For most customers, no action is required.
Modern web browsers (like Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox) and up-to-date operating systems already trust the new DigiCert Global Root G3 certificate automatically.

However, if your organization manages certificates manually or maintains its own trust store, your technical team should add the new G3 certificate before the March 2026 deadline.
This ensures continued, secure access to SAP BTP services.

Important: Do not remove the existing G2 certificate — both should remain active during the transition.

Why This Matters

This change is part of SAP’s ongoing commitment to:

  • Keep your data and applications secure
  • Align with the latest global and national security standards
  • Ensure continued compatibility with modern browsers and systems

By making this upgrade, SAP is helping customers stay protected and ready for the future.

Timeline

The full migration to DigiCert Global Root G3 will take effect in March 2026.

Until then, both the G2 and G3 certificates will remain active to ensure a smooth transition.

How to Add the DigiCert Global Root G3 Certificate

If you manage your own trust stores, please follow these steps:

  1. Visit the DigiCert root certificate page: https://www.digicert.com/kb/digicert-root-certificates.htm
  2. Locate “DigiCert Global Root G3.”
  3. Download the appropriate certificate format for your environment.
  4. Verify the certificate fingerprint using your preferred tool (for example, with OpenSSL:
    openssl x509 -noout -text -in ./DigiCertGlobalRootG3.crt.pem -fingerprint)
  5. Follow your trust store’s instructions to add the certificate.

For guidance on managing trusted certificates for SAP BTP, see the BTP Trust Store on GitHub. To streamline future updates, we recommend applying the BTP Trust Store regularly or automating this process.

Affected Domains

This update applies to the following platform domains in the SAP BTP Neo environment:

*.<Region.Domain> 

*.dispatcher.<Region.Domain> 

*.cert.<Region.Domain> 

*.static.<Region.Domain> 

*.vms.<Region.Domain> 

*.netweaver.ondemand.com 

connectivitynotification.<Region.Domain> 

connectivitytunnel.<Region.Domain>

For a full overview of regions and domain hosts, see the SAP Help Portal.

Custom Domains

SAP-owned custom domains are not affected by this change until March 2026.
After this date, all new automated certificate renewals will use the DigiCert Global Root G3 certificate. New SAP-owned custom domains created after March 2026 will also use G3 by default.


Staying secure is a shared effort — and we’re making it easier for you.
With the DigiCert Global Root G3 upgrade, SAP BTP continues to offer a trusted, reliable, and compliant cloud environment for your business.

entry.title: How to Call an SAP BTP Kyma Function from AWS Lambda — Step by Step
entry.content:
Ever tried to make AWS Lambda talk to a Kyma Function on SAP BTP and ended up buried in docs and 400 errors? Same. In this post, I’ll walk you through the simplest setup that actually works — a Lambda sending JSON to Kyma over HTTPS, step by step.

(From the code snippets, substitute, 'KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN' for your Kyma Cluster Domain).

To recreate this setup, you only need a few free-tier tools and basic access:

Accounts & Platforms

  • AWS Free Tier account – with permissions to create and run a Lambda function.
  • SAP BTP Free Tier account – with access to the Kyma runtime (trial or free tier).
  • GitHub (optional) – if you want to version your function or YAML files.

Local Tools

  • Shell or Terminal – any terminal works (Mac Terminal, Windows PowerShell, WSL, etc.).
  • kubectl – the Kubernetes CLI, configured to connect to your Kyma cluster.
  • Visual Studio Code (VSC) – for editing the function code and YAML files (not strictly necessary, but a nice to have!)
  • curl – to test your public Kyma endpoint from the command line.

First, we will create a function called, 'message-function'. You'll find Functions are under Namespaces->your_namespace->Functions

Click on, 'Create', name it, 'message-function', set the Language to' JavaScript' and the Runtime to, 'Nodejs 22'and leave the rest as default. 

In the, 'Source' tab, add the below code: 

module.exports = {
  main: async function (event, context) {
    let input;
    try {
      if (!event.data) {
        input = {};
      } else if (typeof event.data === "string") {
        input = JSON.parse(event.data);
      } else {
        input = event.data;
      }
    } catch (err) {
      console.error("Parse error:", err.message);
      return {
        statusCode: 400,
        body: {
          error: "Invalid JSON payload",
          details: err.message
        }
      };
    }

    console.log("Received payload:", input);

    return {
      statusCode: 200,
      body: {
        message: "Hello from Kyma — message-function working!",
        received: input
      }
    };
  }
};

Click, 'Create': 

Click, 'save' and wait for the status of the function to turn to a, 'Running' state (here you can see it in an, 'unknown' state: 

It should go to 'Ready' in a couple of seconds or so: 

Create a file named message-function-apirule.yaml with this content:

Then apply it: 

ac:ui5-test neilaspin$ kubectl apply -f message-function-apirule.yaml

You should see: 

apirule.gateway.kyma-project.io/message-function created

Then check ('-n' specifies the namespace that you're using):

kubectl get apirule -n dev

 You should get something like this back: 

message-function     Ready ["message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN"]

Test it again: 

$ curl -X POST https://message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN>   -H "Content-Type: application/json"   -d '{"test":"direct"}'

You should see something like this: 

Hello world from the Kyma Function message-function running on nodejs22!(base)

Now lets work through the Lambda stuff!
In AWS Console->Lambda->Functions->Create Function

Add the below code into your 'index.mjs' file: 

// index.js (CommonJS)
const https = require("https");

exports.handler = async (event) => {
  const data = JSON.stringify({
    from: "AWS Lambda",
    time: new Date().toISOString(),
    echo: event || {}
  });

  const options = {
    hostname: "message-function.<KYMA_CLUSTER_DOMAIN>",
    port: 443,
    path: "/",
    method: "POST",
    headers: {
      "Content-Type": "application/json",
      "Content-Length": Buffer.byteLength(data)
    }
  };

  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    const req = https.request(options, (res) => {
      let body = "";
      res.on("data", (chunk) => (body += chunk));
      res.on("end", () => {
        console.log("Kyma replied:", body);
        resolve({ statusCode: res.statusCode, body });
      });
    });

    req.on("error", (err) => {
      console.error("HTTPS error:", err);
      reject(err);
    });

    req.write(data);
    req.end();
  });
};

Create a Test Event with the Even JSON set to '{ "hello": "world" }': 

Click, 'Test' in the top right corner
Then you should see : 

Click on the, 'logs' link (this should take you to CloudWatch): 

Click on the latest logstream at the bottom of the page and you should see some output like below: 

And we're golden!

2025-10-17T07:24:39.081Z	141aa77f-cbdd-4c28-b74a-d56c18519d3e	INFO	Kyma replied: Hello world from the Kyma Function message-function running on nodejs22!

Conclusion: 

With just a Kyma Function, an APIRule, and a few lines of Node.js in AWS Lambda, we’ve built a working integration between AWS and SAP BTP. The Lambda sends a simple JSON payload over HTTPS, Kyma processes it, and responds in real time. This pattern is lightweight, reliable, and scalable — perfect for triggering SAP workloads from AWS events without introducing extra middleware or services.

entry.title: Re: SAP FSM Smartform is read-only
entry.content:
Usually the only reason a smartform is read-only is that the person opening it is not set as responsible person. Have you tried using the "Take it" action on the activity and confirm to also take over smartforms? Maybe that fixes as a workaround and better then deleting and recreating?

Otherwise it needs some troubleshooting why sometimes the responsible person is not set correctly in the business rule. Some questions to check:

1. Did you check via query the ids of the responsible person set?

2. Is this happening always for the same users or different people?

3. Any pattern when it works and when it does not work?

If you cannot find out the root cause and fix might be worth to create a support ticket.

entry.title: Overhead costs in Maintenance Orders, Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Collaborative effort of Saurabh Goyal.

Overhead costs in maintenance refer to the indirect expenses associated with keeping assets, equipment, facilities, or infrastructure operational, but that are not directly tied to a specific maintenance task or job.

Why it matters?

  • Maintenance overheads affect the total cost of ownership of equipment.
  • Businesses need to track and allocate these costs accurately to understand true operational expenses.
  • Understanding overhead costs helps in making decisions on repair vs. replace, outsourcing, or investing in predictive maintenance tools.

This blog outlines the necessary process and configuration required to perform this calculation in the public cloud. It also highlights the associated constraints and provides guidance for customers and partners on how to proceed.

Define Costing Sheet (SSCUI 102922 Define Costing Sheets )

Define the material overhead rates for corresponding plant actual /planned

Planning Costing SheetProduction Costing Sheet

Configuration of the assignment costing sheet to valuation variant (SSCUI 102607 :Define Valuation Variants for Material Cost Estimates)

Assign planning costing sheet to valuation variant 006 and production costing sheet to valuation variant 007

Configure Overhead Costs value category for maintenance Order (SSCUI 103792 Maintain Value Categories)

Configure Value category for Maintenance orders. Create a new value category for Overhead costs

Assign relevant Cost element group to newly created value category (SSCUI 103806:Assign Cost Elements to Value Categories)

Overhead calculation as per costing sheet

As you create maintenance order, add material to operation and save, the planned overhead costs are calculated and same is reflected in the costs tab in Overhead costs value category.

In the backend the costing sheet is filled with the costing sheet which we assigned in the configuration SSCUI 102607 above as maintenance order is assigned with costing sheet.

In the below maintenance order we created, the material value is 120000 EUR and corresponding overhead costs according to the overhead rate 7% in the costing sheet will be 0.07*120000 = 8400 EUR

Planned costs updated under cost category overhead costs

Goods issue on the maintenance order

Goods Issue

Run overhead calculation actual

Material Overhead costs calculated

The same is reflected in actual costs for overhead cost category in the maintenance order

Actual overhead costs reflection on Maintenance Order

As illustrated in the scenario above, configuring the costing sheet within the valuation variant enables the business to calculate overhead costs effectively. However, this approach does come with certain limitations, which are outlined in the section below.

Constraints to the process:

  • Since the field is hidden, the process cannot be altered during runtime.

Available options:

  • Assignment of costing sheet to maintenance order type. Customer / partner can vote to the CIP request https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/333625
  • For additional features, new request can be raised.

Thanks for your time and please share your valuable feedback and inputs in a comment below. Also kindly follow the tag SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Asset Management to watch similar content.

You can also post your questions at All Questions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Asset Management | SAP Community

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi  @OlgaDolinskaja 

We've been running Clean Core checks using a 758 Central system and a 757 Target system.

We now have access to a new BTP system running 2508 HFC 7, which we'd like to use as our ATC Central system. We also plan to move our Target system to a 758 release, since certain Clean Core checks cannot be executed on a 757 remote system.

Overall, we're quite impressed with the improvements when reviewing ATC checks in BTP with the Custom Code Analysis App, especially the benefits of a more modern and intuitive UI!

However, we've noticed a few differences between running ATC checks in BTP and a 758 system:

1) Missing Clean Core Checks

  • After implementing Note 3565942 on our 758 Central system, the Clean Core checks were added under the variant ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT
  • However, this variant in our BTP system does not include those Clean Core checks, even though our BTP environment is on the latest hotfix collection (2508 HFC 7)
  • Is there any additional configuration or setup required in BTP to enable the Clean Core checks in variant ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT?

2) ATC Result discrepancies between 758 and BTP

  • We created copies of the ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT variant in both 758 and BTP 2508 HFC 7
  • The only difference is that the BTP variant lacks the Clean Core checks, since they don't exist there
  • When comparing ATC results for the same Target system/packages, the BTP run produced significantly more warnings than the 758 run, which surprised us,  especially given that the Clean Core checks were not active in BTP
  • Is it expected that the same ATC variant would yield more warnings in BTP than in a 758 system?
  • Possibly this behavior could be related to the missing Clean Core checks in BTP?

3) Quick Fix Proposal Option

  • In the 758 system, there's an option to 'Calculate Quick Fix Proposals' for an ATC run, however this option isn't available in BTP
  • We assume that in BTP, quick fix proposals are calculated automatically even though the option isn't visible, is this assumption correct?

entry.title: Student trying to break in into SAP? I've a few insights
entry.content:
So you're a student or recent grad trying to break into SAP, and honestly? I know every job posting seems to want "2-3 years of experience." 

Let me break it down for you. Most of you just need a game plan instead of falling down random YouTube "tech" rabbit holes.

I've helped a ton of people get started in SAP (and watched quite a few become consultants), so here's the "good" pattern I saw:

1. Stop trying to learn everything at once

SAP is huge. Like, overwhelming huge. It's got finance stuff (FICO), supply chain (MM), sales (SD), HR (SuccessFactors)... the list goes on. Here's the thing though, you don't need to master it all. Pick ONE area that makes sense for your background. Most of you are not starting from scratch. For example: Studied accounting? Start with finance modules. Have an HR degree? SuccessFactors might be your lane.

Bottom line: Go deep in one area first. You can always branch out later.

2. Create your own experience

Trust me: recruiters aren't expecting you to have years of SAP experience yet. They just want to see that you're actually doing something. You can get hands-on through:

  • Free SAP learning platforms (SAP Learning has student editions, BTP has a Free Trial - just dig out there)
  • Practice environments where you can click around and experiment
  • Creating sample projects — even walking through a basic business process counts. 

Post about it on LinkedIn. Something like "Finally figured out how purchasing workflows work in SAP MM today ". It might sounds small, but very important for decision makers to notice you.

3. LinkedIn > your GPA (seriously)

I've watched people with okay grades but solid LinkedIn profiles get hired in like 3 months. Why? Because that's where recruiters are looking first.

Your headline should actually say what you're working toward: "Future SAP Consultant | Finance Grad | Currently Learning FICO & S/4HANA"

Simple change, but it tells people you're serious and helps the right opportunities find you.

4. Certifications help, but they're not everything

Yeah, getting certified can open doors. But what keeps those doors open? Actually understanding how to solve business problems with SAP. In interviews, the person who can explain why a company would use SAP beats the person who just memorized exam questions every time.

5. You're actually ahead of the curve

A lot of the experienced consultants are moving into senior roles, which means there's huge demand for fresh talent right now. If you start learning today and stay consistent, you're positioning yourself perfectly.

My take? Pick your module/solution. Practice regularly . Share what you're learning online. Don't wait until you "feel ready" — you'll get ready by actually doing it.

Keep at it. Important: Collaborate here with the SAP Community - there's always someone going through the same challenges as you.

Daniel Kiel
https://www.linkedin.com/in/danielkiel/

entry.title: Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
entry.content:
In our first post, we introduced the SAP Fiori development portal and explored the concept of building blocks. Now it's time to dive deeper and see how this portal unlocks the full potential of these enterprise-ready components. Whether you're a developer, designer, or business analyst, the portal provides an intuitive way to explore, understand, and leverage the comprehensive capabilities that SAP Fiori elements building blocks offer.

Exploring the Portal's Structure

The SAP Fiori development portal organizes everything you need into four main sections, each designed to guide you through different aspects of SAP Fiori app development

Building Blocks - This is where the magic begins. Here you'll find all available building blocks, from the fundamental field component that forms the foundation of nearly every application, to sophisticated components like tables and charts. Each building block comes packed with enterprise-grade features that would take months to develop from scratch.

Global Patterns - Don't overlook this section! These non-visual building blocks are what make your applications truly enterprise-ready. Features like draft handling, internal and external navigation, and error handling ensure your apps meet the high standards users expect from SAP applications.

Standard Floorplans - When you need proven layouts fast, this section provides predefined combinations of building blocks optimized for common use cases like List Report and Object Page. These floorplans represent years of UX research and customer feedback, delivering consistency and developer productivity. The section also helps you explore the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements to extend the standard floorplans. If your targeted SAP Fiori app is close to a standard floorplan, extending it using the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements gets you to the result easily and quickly.

Custom Pages - For unique requirements, this section shows you how to combine both visual and non-visual building blocks to create custom layouts while retaining all the enterprise features and annotation-driven benefits.

Structured Feature List

 

The Power Behind Every Building Block

What makes these building blocks truly powerful isn't just their visual appeal - it's the comprehensive feature set that comes built-in. Take the table building block, for example. Out of the box, you get:

  • Personalization capabilities that let users customize their view
  • Variant management for saving and sharing different table configurations
  • Export and import functionality for seamless data exchange
  • Multiple visualization options to present data in the most effective way
  • Extension points that allow developers to add custom functionality without breaking the core features
  • Responsive behavior that adapts to different screen sizes and devices
  • Accessibility compliance ensuring your apps work for all users

This enterprise-grade functionality would typically require significant development effort, but with SAP Fiori elements building blocks, it's available immediately through simple annotations.

Hands-On Exploration Made Easy

Every page in the portal follows a consistent structure designed for learning and experimentation:

  • Focused introduction - Each feature gets a clear, concise explanation
  • Live samples - See the building block in action with real data in both display and edit modes
  • Implementation guidance - Clear instructions showing the annotations, manifest settings, or code needed
  • Multiple annotation formats - Examples in CAP CDS, RAP CDS, and XML annotations for maximum compatibility
  • Live code editing - The integrated code editor lets you experiment and see changes instantly
  • Further reading - Use the link to the specific product documentation to understand further details

Page Overview

 

What's Next

In our next post, we'll explore how complex building blocks can be combined to create sophisticated user interfaces that handle the most demanding business scenarios. We'll show you how the portal helps you understand the relationships between different building blocks and guides you in creating cohesive, powerful applications.

To get the full overview about the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:
  • Development (1/6) Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your... - SAP Community
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @DouglasCapo,

thank you for your nice impressions, the ATC on SAP BTP really took one step further to become more user-friendly and intuitive.

The new clean core checks  in SAP BTP ABAP environment 2508 are available in the ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT check variant under the 3-Tier Model check category, the Search for customer modifications check under the Search functions category and the Critical statements check under the Security category.

In the upcoming 2511 version these 4 checks  will be conveniently offered under the new Clean Core check category and in addition the new ATC check variant ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT will be delivered, containing all recommended ATC checks fo clean core governance.

Please execute your ATC run using the clean core checks. The quick fix proposals with ATC on BTP are calculated automatically and available as a separate visual filter for filtering results.

Best regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to configure Geofencing in SuccessFactors Time Tracking
entry.content:
Overview:

It’s just before 9 AM. You’re scrolling through emails / messages before going in. You open the SuccessFactors app to clock in, but it won’t let you.

That’s geo-fencing at work.

Think of it like an invisible fence around your workplace. Until you actually walk through the doors or at least get close enough to be within that set boundary, you won’t be able to clock in or out. It’s a simple way to make sure people are physically present when logging their time. No tricks, no guesswork just accurate, location-based tracking.

SAP SuccessFactors formally introduces native Geo-Fencing functionality for Clock In Clock Out (CICO) through the mobile app in the 2H 2025 release.

Prerequisites:

Before getting into the configuration process, ensure you have the necessary permissions:

  1. Administrator Permissions -> Manage Geofences -> Create.
  2. Manage Geofences -> Assign Geofence Access by Feature Area, which enables assigning geofences to specific feature areas.

Configuration Steps:

Step 1 - Creating Geofences

  1. Go to the Manage Geofences in search bar.
  2. To create new Geofence, click Create.
  3. Add meaningful name and code in Basic information, so that it can be easily recognized.
  4. Update Zones and find the area you want by using the location search.
  5. Based on your area required, select between a square or round zone shape.
  6. To specify the geofence's limits, add the exact longitude and latitude coordinates and the radius in meters.
  7. Click Create, a map view of configured zone will be visible.

Step 2: Assign Geofences to Clock In and Clock Out Group

  1. Go to Configure Clock In and Clock Out
  2. Select Clock In/Clock Out Groups and choose the group you wish to edit.
  3. Enable Location Capture and Geofences for this group.
  4. Assign geofence(s) under Geofence Assignments, with Time Event Type.

Testing:

To validate how well the Time Tracking feature with Geofencing works in SAP SuccessFactors, the following test scenarios were run using the SF mobile app: 

  1. Outside Geofence (Head Office Location): When accessing the Clock In/Out tab in the mobile app while outside the head office's geofenced area, the punch options were greyed out, indicating that the user is outside the allowed area for time tracking.
  2. Within Geofence: As configured when user is in 50 meters range of the head office, Clock In/Out becomes active. The user can successfully clock in and out.

                

Conclusion:

This new feature is a step towards smarter and more responsive time management practices.

Let’s Hear From You!

entry.title: 2H 2025 - Release highlights of SuccessFactors Time Management
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

As you all know its 2H 2025 Release Month and Here are some of the Release Features which every time consultant must know.

1) Compare threshold with comparison group to route input has been renames as Route Input based on Decision.

2)  Geofencing for clock times 
Now you can set a predefined office location where you want to record certain time event types only within that area. This feature is available only for mobile as of now and it uses Google Maps to fetch the location which gives better accuracy.

 

 

 3)  Automatic Synchronization of Clock in Clock Out Employees Supported for Leave of Absence

When an employee goes on a Leave of Absence (LOA) or returns from a LOA, it is no longer needed to perform a manual employee synchronization for Clock In Clock Out users. Previously manual sync is needed to reflect the changes after LOA and RTW but now system automatically sync up the data to synchronize clock in clock out.

 

 4)  Automatic Time Management configurations available in Configure Transport Center
Now you can copy and move the clock in clock out transaction objects with transport center which makes the work more easy

 5)  Time Sheet Change Audit Document for an Employee Self-Service Scenario

Employees can now download their time sheet audit statement that acts as a report of their time sheet entries

 

 6) TLMTriggerTasks Job available in Scheduled Job UI

Earlier TLMTriggerTask job has to be scheduled from Provisioning system but now you can schedule it Via instance system through scheduled job manager transaction.

 7)  Counting Records in a Time Type Group

Create Time Record time valuation type has been enhanced to count the number of recordings in a time type group or directly generate a fixed counted event.

 

😎 Automatic Recalculation of Holiday Calendar Object

Now an automatic recalculation occurs to Holiday Calendar object when you edit or add any holiday. For this you must enable option in time management configuration as shown below:

 I hope the above features help you to maintain system accuracy and up to date.

Thank You!

entry.title: Beyond Manual: SuccessFactors Custom MDF & Integration Center for Automated Reimbursement Process
entry.content:
Symptoms:
 In mid-to-large sized companies, HR officers often face a lot of challenges managing the reimbursement Requests raised each month. This process can become time consuming and labor intensive due to the variety of request types and calculation rules (business travel, visa charges…).
commonly these requests are submitted by email. After that the approval and the data entry into the payroll system will be performed manually. However, this will always lead to delayed payments and increased errors.
Process flow:

 


                                                                                                                             

Concept:
For a smoother and streamlined process, we must implement a fully automated solution, consider implementing a custom MDF object within SuccessFactors for each reimbursement category, for centralized payments governance.
 Yet, this solution will only cover Step 1 and 2 of the process flow. ⚠️

Limitations:
Data circulation from custom MDF objects to the standard SuccessFactors objects, is not supported using business rules (refer to SAP KBA 2562069 for details).

✅Standards to Custom MDF => Data propagation allowed via Business Rules
❌Custom MDF to Standards => Data propagation NOT allowed via Business Rules

Enhancement:
To cover the last step of the process flow (posting payments to payroll) and further enable full automation. We need to create an internal Integration Job using the SuccessFactors Integration Center (IC).

In the following section, we will guide you through the exact IC configuration steps.

How to map?

Search Integration Center, My Integrations => Create => More Integration Types.

 


To fill data into One-Time Payments (which is standard portlet), use a scheduled Integration Center job. Then Select all required fields, as framed in the screenshot below.

1.Select the Data Source: (Custom MDF object)
Search for your cust_MDF => Select

2.Select the Target object: (Standard Object)
Click Add Button

Search the Target MDF object (Non-Recurring Payments) => Select the destination Fields one after the other.

From the right corner, choose the mapping type for the fields(based on your need):

  • Set as Fixed Value Field: Used to Give fixed value to the destination field (e.g. Fixed payment type or currency).
  • Set as Association Field: Used to Directly get data from your Source Object. Drag the source field and drop it into the desired Target Field (e.g. The Total payment amount, the creation date…).
  • Set as Calculation Field: Used to Dynamically fill Data into the Target field based on data from 1 or more Source Fields. (e.g. generation of payment amounts using predefined formula rather than direct mapping).

3.Add filters and sorts: (Optional But Important⚠️)

First, we need to understand what are the different types of filters that we have:
a. Advanced Filters: Used to specify more complex conditional expressions than are  possible with the simple filters.
b. Time-Based Filters: Helps to get all the records (current and/or historical) that have been modified since the last time the integration ran.
c. Advanced Sorting: Used to sort the output records.”
 Source(https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/using-integration-center/filter-and-sort)
In our case will need to apply Time-Based Filter=>"Effective From Date", because we need to read and propagate all New, Old, and/or Changed records, not just the latest one.
(for more details please refer to KBA 2470903)

Important Note: ⚠️⚠️
If approved records only need to be Auto-created under one-time payment, please ensure to enable the pending Data fields in your Source Object definition:
 1. Access "Configure Object Definitions.

 2. Search for your Source Cust-MDF object.

 3. set the "Pending Data field" to YES

This way we ensure that the Integration will consider the requests with Approved Status only.

4. Schedule your Integration, then review and save.


By reaching this stage, we have successfully implemented a fully automated reimbursement Process .

5. Reporting: (Optional But Important⚠️)

To verify and track data it’s recommended to create two reports using the report center:
 1. Reimbursement Requests per Type
 2. Non-Recurring payment amounts per Reimbursement type.

Conclusion:
Combining Custom MDF Objects with SuccessFactors Integration center can serve the organizations’ needs to overcome the Business rule limitation and fully automate the Data propagation from Custom to Standard Objects. This can be achieved with Simple Configuration steps Starting By creating new Integration type, Selecting the Source object (Custom MDF), Choosing the Target object (Standard MDF), then configuring the appropriate Field mapping (Fixed, association, or calculated), Optionally applying Filters and Sorting (Advanced, Time-based, …), and Finally Schedule the Job to run at your preferred Frequency. 

References:
2209164 - How to enable Integration Center in SuccessFactors System? - SAP SuccessFactors HXM Suite
2701195 - SuccessFactors to SuccessFactors integration - Integration Center
2655688 - How to Set a Schedule for Integration Center Jobs Using SuccessFactors Integration Center
2470903 - Integration Center is not returning historical/future records
2742107 - Integration Center: Frequently Asked Questions
2562069 - Scenario-based business rules for MDF objects, Parameters, Limitations, and other information about custom MDF Business Rule configuration scenario
https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/using-integration-center/integration-center?locale...
