entry.title: End-to-End Process of Time-Based Preventive Maintenance in SAP PM
entry.content:
Preventive Maintenance is a business process which is being used for maintaining the equipment before it gets into breakdown or to reduce the downtime of the equipment so that the production will be continue making of finished goods.

There are three types of preventive maintenance process: -

To analyse or to get familiar with preventive maintenance we must understand about maintenance strategy.

STEP 1:-

MAINTENANCE STARTEGY: -

Maintenance strategy will define the packages or frequencies and represent the rule for preventive maintenance. Maintenance strategy can be created for both time-based maintenance plan as well as performance-based maintenance plan.

Let's come to business terms where a maintenance strategy will be used. Consider an equipment where it must be maintained for every 15 days,30 days,60 days. This type of sequence can be maintained in maintenance strategy, and also if counter has received a particular counter reading then these all can be maintenance in SAP maintenance strategy and it can be assigned to the maintenance task list.

To create a maintenance strategy, we will navigate to the T-code IP11.

or else you can follow the path too as shown in below: -

Logistics --> Plant Maintenance --> Preventive Maintenance --> Maintenance Planning --> Maintenance strategies --> Create. 

TIME BASED MAINTENANCE STARTEGY: -

Here click on new entries and then you will navigate to the next screen. Here i am creating a time-based maintenance strategy.

Here you will be maintaining the above parameters namely: -

  • Scheduling Indicator: -

In scheduling indicator, you can observe there are 3 types of scheduling namely

Let us say a maintenance plan is being scheduled in the system and the above the scheduling indicator is set as follows based on it the orders will get generates.

  • Time
  • Time- Key Date
  • Time Factory Calendar
  1. Scheduling Indicator as Time: -

If the scheduling indicator is set to TIME, the maintenance plan is scheduled based on the date it was initially planned, and the next maintenance order will be generated exactly 30 days after that date, without considering holidays.

For example: -

if a maintenance plan is scheduled on 13-10-2025 then exactly irrespective of holidays irrespective of weekends the maintenance order will gets generated exactly after 30 days that is on 12-11-2025.

  1. Scheduling Indicator as Time- Key Date: -

If the scheduling indicator is set to TIME – KEY DATE, the maintenance plan is scheduled based on the specified key date, and the next maintenance order will be generated exactly 30 days after that date.

For example: -

if a maintenance plan is scheduled on 13-10-2025 then the maintenance order will gets generated exactly on the same date 13-11-2025.

  1. Scheduling Indicator as Time - Factory Calendar: -

If the scheduling indicator is set to TIME – FACTORY CALENDAR, the maintenance plan is scheduled based on the factory calendar, and the next maintenance order will be generated 30 days later, considering holidays, weekends, and other non-working days defined in the factory calendar.

For example: -

if a maintenance plan is scheduled on 13-10-2025 then the maintenance order will gets generated on the date 23-11-2025 by considering the holidays, weekends, festival holidays etc.

  • Strategy Unit: -

This the unit of measurement in which the maintenance strategy must be measured it can be any type but mostly we will use HR, DAY, D in SAP PM.

  • Call Horizon: -

Let us say you can plan the materials if the order is being called before the execution date it means if the order got called on the same date there might be a chance of capacity of people available on the execution of maintenance order might not be there or else any unavailability of materials then to plan all these activities we can use call horizon.

Before going into call horizon let us be clear with 2 terms namely plan date and call date.

  • Plan date: - The date on which the maintenance activity or maintenance order needs to be performed on the equipment or and asset.
  • Call date: - The Call Date is the date on which a maintenance call (order or notification) is generated from a maintenance plan.

So here the call horizon will be maintained in the format percentage like (0-100) %. Based on the percentage the maintenance order will be called.

Example: -

Let us consider the cycle as 30 days and here we have maintained the call horizon as below:

100% -----> call date and plan date will be same

90% -----> Call date will be 90% of 30days then it will be 27 days before so it means on the 27th day from the scheduled date of maintenance plan the maintenance order will be called and here the there is a gap of 3 days to plan the activities.

80% ----> Call date will be 80% of 30days then it will be 24 days before so it means on the 24th day from the scheduled date of maintenance plan the maintenance order will be called and here the there is a gap of 6 days to plan the activities.

Like above we can see that the maintenance orders will be called before the plan date because to plan the activities like whether the materials are there or not else the capacity of people or workers are being available on the plan date or not on the maintenance order date. By maintaining the call horizon, we can achieve this.

  • Shift Factor for Late & Early Completion: -

Shift Factor for late & early completion both characteristics and properties are but they act different from each other.

Shift Factor for Late Completion: -

Let us consider a maintenance order is called on 01-10-2025 and the confirmation date got delayed and the last operation in work order got confirmed on the 15-10-2025 and you can also see the next maintenance order is being called on the date 01-11-2025.

And here you want to shift the maintenance order that is going to be called on the 01-11-2025 to the next dates so you have maintained the shift factor for late completion and the format it is in numeric that to from (0-100).

If you maintain the shift factor for late completion as 100% then next work order will be generated after 15 days on the 15-11-2025 and if you maintain it as 50% then 50% of 15 days, then the next work order will be shifted by 8 days.

Same applies for Early completion too. In early completion the maintenance orders will be shifted to before the plan date.

  • Tolerance Key: -

The tolerance key will be maintained in the percentage format. Here it will be determining the no. of days that it will be take or the no. of days the maintenance order or work order from the plan date can be in process. The last operation confirmation date matters here.

For example, let us take you have maintained the tolerance key as 10% for a 30-day cycle. It means that 10% of 30days which will give us a result of 3 days so 3 days is the time for all the operations in the maintenance order to get confirmed.

10% of 30 days ---> 3-day time

20% of 30 days ---> 6-day time

30% of 30 days ----> 9-day time .... etc...

If beyond this time the confirmation is done like the maintenance order gets delayed and you have maintained the tolerance key for late completion, then the shift factor for late or early completion condition will affects the maintenance plan.

  • Factory Calendar: -

The factory calendar will be maintained by FICO consultant based on the client requirements here we will assign the factory calendar based on it the maintenance strategy will behave.

STEP 2:-

After maintaining the parameters, you just need to click on the packages where you will be defining the intervals of the strategy unit.

Here maintain the activities or the cycle length and then click on the package sequence here. After clicking on the package sequence, you can find the screen as below where the operations are being done based on the hierarchy.

Because of the package sequence only the order or the maintenance activities are being called, and the package sequence is maintained ion the maintenance strategy. Here it means that the activities that are going to be done on 15 days or 2 weeks will not have priority on 30 days and the maintenance activities that are being done on 30 days will not have the priority on 45 days.

 Basically, it means the activities that are going to be executed on 15 days will not be repeated on 30 days and the activities that are going to be done 30 days will not be repeated on 45 days.

Here is you maintain the hierarchy for all the package sequence as 1 for each and every cycle length then the package sequence will be as below it means each and every option will have the priority and each activity that is going to be done on 15 days has to be done on 30 days , 45 days , 90 days etc...

Here this will be decided by the business what type of package and what are the hierarchy numbers that we need to maintain to generate the orders based on the maintenance activities.

The next step is creation of maintenance task list for equipment or functional location or general task list.

STEP 3:-

TASK LIST: -

The task list will be created based on the business requirement it can be any one of the following namely

  1. Functional Location Task List (Creation: -IA11)
  2. Equipment Task List (Creation: - IA01)
  3. General Task List (creation: - IA05)

Here I am taking an example of equipment task list so just navigate ti the t-code IA01 and just enter the following details.

Here maintain the following details: -

Work center: - will be picked up from the equipment master record.

Usage: - Since it is plant maintenance, we will be assigning the number 4- Plant Maintenance

Planner Group: - A group of people who are responsible for planning the activities.

Overall status: - mainly the overall status will be used as 4 ---> released (General).

System Condition: - The system condition will define whether the equipment or machine is idle, or production is going on the machine.

Maintenance Strategy: - here the maintenance strategy will be used whether it might be time based, or performance-based strategy also can be assigned to the task list.

If you assign the maintenance strategy, then a function will be enabled on the screen if you click on the operations which is present in the application toolbar.

If you assign the maintenance strategy, then the maintenance package function got enabled and then there we will assign the task on which the month.

In the maintenance package of the equipment task list, we assign the operations that need to be performed during each maintenance cycle.

After assigning the maintenance packages for the task list then save it. Like wise you can also create for performance-based maintenance plan too in which we will also maintain the maintenance package as same as above.

STEP 4:-

MAINTENANCE PLANS: -

Maintenance plans are used to generate a call object automatically on a particular date. And the call object can be of anything but mostly of the time the following are being used in sap EAM.

  1. Maintenance Order
  2. Maintenance Notification
  3. Service procurement
  4. Inspection (only Notification)

Different types of maintenance plans: -

  • multiple counter plan (IP43)
  • strategy plan (IP42)
  • Single cycle plan (IP41)

Now the flow of maintenance plan will be in the format as follows: -

Maintenance strategy ---> Task list ----> Maintenance item ----> Maintenance plan ------> Scheduling of maintenance plan --->Call Objects   (order, notification, service procurement).

Now for creation of maintenance plan we will navigate to the t-code IP42 and here we will assign the maintenance strategy.

STEP 5:-

And we will be assigning the task list related to the equipment at the bottom side of the task list related to the equipment or functional location.

Here just maintain the task list which was previously created and if you want to create a new task list you can just click on the create button which is present right of the description. As soon as the task list is being assigned to the maintenance plan the cycles will be picked from the maintenance task list.

STEP 6:-

So here we can observe that the cycles got picked from the maintenance task list. After the cycles got picked up from the maintenance task list, we will just navigate to the next tab maintenance plan scheduling parameters. Here the values of call horizon, shift factor all the details will be picked up from the maintenance strategy.

Here all the shift factor, tolerance, scheduling period, scheduling indicator, all the details will be taken from the maintenance strategy and then there are some terms which are necessary to know.

Completion Requirement: - Here the completion requirement is a checkbox in which the previous generated order from the maintenance plan must be completed (the system status needs to be TECO) then only the maintenance plan will generate the next order.

Cycle Modification Factor: - Here the cycle modification factor plays a crucial role if it is being maintained let us take an example like there is cycle length which is being maintained in the maintenance strategy.

If I have maintained it by 1.50 then it will get multiplied with each of the cycle length and the cycle will be increased.

 

Actual cycle length

Modification factor

After applying the modification factor

New Cycle Length

15 days

1.5

15 days *1.5     = 23 days

23 days

30 days

1.5

30 days * 1.5    = 45 days

45 days

90 days

1.5

90 days * 1.5    = 135 days

135 days

180 days

1.5

180 days * 1.5  = 270 days

270 days

360 days

1.5

360 days * 1.5  = 540 days

540 days

Now next we will navigate to the next tab which is present beside the maintenance plan additional data where sort field and authorization group can be maintained.

Sort field: - Here we can maintain the sort field to sort the maintenance plan based on it we can sort or filter the maintenance plans.

Authorization Group: - If any authorization group is present then we will maintain it here it means those people who are being considered in the authorization group can have the access of changing or setting the deletion flag.

Then the maintenance plan will be saved, and the system will generate a maintenance plan number based on the number ranges which are being configured in the configuration path.

Here it will ask for the cycle start date it means on which date the maintenance plan has to start or if you select NO you will not specify the date here and to schedule the maintenance plan we will be navigating to the t-code IP10 and here by entering the maintenance plan number we will just schedule it. If you select the radio button as YES then you must specify the date, and the maintenance plan will automatically get scheduled.

Navigate to the T-CODE IP10.

Enter the maintenance plan number and then after click on the start button there we can enter the maintenance plan date on which date from the maintenance plan has to start.

Here there are options namely start and start in cycle in which

Start :- from which date the maintenance plan must start.

Start In Cycle : - on which date the last maintenance has been completed and what is the next maintenance.

here if you click on the start in cycle then you have selected the completion date completion time and the offset time too.

Here for example the 30days maintenance activity is already being done then the one month will be selected and then we will use the function set offset start which is present in the application toolbar.

Here after selecting the offset, we can observe the offset is being set at the time or cycle which we have selected.

Here I am just trying to schedule the maintenance plan by clicking on the start function in the application toolbar. After clicking on the start function in the application toolbar, we can be able to see the plan dates and call dates of the maintenance orders in the screen.

Here you can observe the plan date and call date both are different, and the call date is on 26.10.2025 whereas the plan date is on 29.10.2025 it means there is 3 days of buffer time is present it means that the planner can plan the materials, capacity of people etc...

STEP 7:-Now I will save the maintenance plan and for deadline monitoring we will be using the t-code IP30.

After entering the maintenance plan number, we will execute the deadline monitoring. and the system will automatically raise the maintenance order, and it will release them too on the proposed dates.

Here you can see the details of the maintenance plan whether it got scheduled or not if there are any errors, we can see the log.

To monitor the maintenance plan with its call date and what are the order that are being generated with reference to which call object we can view all the details in the T-Code IP24.

And in the next screen you can see about what are the order numbers that got generated.

If you want an order to get generated automatically that is the order 29.10.2025 must be generated now you have two ways:-

  1. you can just navigate to the IP10 and here you can see the date and just select the line item and then click on the release button which is present at the bottom of the screen.

then the order number will get generated and you can just follow the Work order to settlement cycle.

  1. If the system needs to generate maintenance orders, we can navigate to transaction code IP30. In this transaction, there is an option called “Interval for Call Objects,” where we specify the number of days between maintenance calls. Based on this interval, the system will automatically generate the maintenance orders when we execute the deadline monitoring.

As you can see that there an order has been created and order number also displayed along with the schedule of maintenance plan.

And you can see the order number through t-code IP30. In which the order number will gets displayed.

If you navigate to the t-code IW32 and enter the order number you can see the system status as released.

And the operations are also got selected from the maintenance plan based on the package sequence which you have selected and if you have just added any components to the operations that are present in the task list then those will also picked from it and will be assigned to the maintenance order.

After this the Goods Issue will be done against the order number for this we will navigate to the t-code MIGO and here we will place the order number and select the drop down as goods issue against order. Check once what is the movement type here and then after you just need to click on the item ok and in the reservation tab we need to click final issue.

The goods will be taken from the inventory and then the maintenance activities will be taken by the maintenance departments and after this we will just do the confirmation of the order by using the t-code IW41 and here we will give the order number and give the operations which are confirmed by the production supervisor.

After confirmation the TECO of the maintenance order will be done and after TECO we will just Inform the Finance team to settle the order at the month end after settlement of order the complete business button which is present on the application toolbar will be executed.

SUMMARY :-
In Plant maintenance or in EAM preventive maintenance will plays crucial part where we will be monitoring the equipment or asset for which what are the maintenance activates that are needed to be carried out based on time. It means a regular maintenance of the equipment or asset will keep them be running as it doesn't effect the production. If production stops then the revenue for the company will stops so to overcome this preventive maintenance will plays a crucial role in any company.

If any clarity needed or any suggestions feel free to comment.

Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Re: Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Hi @GopalAgarwal 

CIS configuration with SAP Ariba is a one off activity, it is not designed to be disabled/re-enabled frequently and as such, disabling configured CIS needs to go through support ticketing.

The right way to handle test-related user accounts authentication on CIS enabled SAP Ariba systems is to have those test users created and authenticated by CIS directly.

In case CIS is configured to delegate user authentication to a federated corporate identity provider (Entra, Okta...ect), use conditional authentication to have CIS directly authenticating those test users instead of sending the authentication request to the corporate idp

entry.title: SAML+OAuth2 (PowerApps --> SAP)
entry.content:
• Overview
  • Basic setup
  • Postman test
  • SAP Integration Suite setup
  • Microsoft PowerPlatform test
  • Troubleshooting

Overview

This setup describes SAP data consumption (S/4HANA) in Microsoft PowerApps with user authentication using Microsoft EntraID. So you could login to Microsoft PowerApps with your EntraID account and use there data from S/4HANA.
If you're interested in the theory and architecture behind this setup, please read this excellent article written by Martin Pankraz.
Steps described here are compatible with S/4HANA On-premise, S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC 6 EHP8, but some screens may look different as screenshots were captured in S/4HANA Private Cloud 2023.

Basic setup

Start by checking that all required services are enabled in T-Code SICF.

  • /sap/bc/webdynpro/sap/saml2
  • /sap/public/bc/sec/saml2
  • /sap/public/bc/sec/cdc_ext_service
  • /sap/public/myssocntl
  • /sap/bc/sec/oauth2/token

Open T-Code SAML2 and enable SAML support. Provider name could be any string, but must be URL compliant! It's best practice to use http://<SID><client>. Switch selection mode to automatic if you intent to use only one IDP.

Local provider is created. Download metadata needed for next steps.

Now go to EntraID and create Enterprise App of type "SAP NetWeaver".

On "Single sign-on" tab click "SAML". New blank configuration will be created. Use "Upload metadata file" button and select metadata file downloaded from SAP. This loads SAP's metadata into EntraID.

Edit "Reply URL" to point to Token service of OAuth2 and don't forget to set correct client in parameter "sap-client". "Sign on URL" could be any URL compliant string (ex. https://dummy.com).

Edit "Attributes & Claims". Click on "Unique User Identifier (Name ID)".

You have two options here, based on attribute that you like to use as user identifier.

  1. If you don't have any email address assigned to more than one user in SAP and you use email as UPN in EntraID, you could match EntraID and SAP user based on email. In this case select "Name identifier format" = "Email address" and "Source attribute" = "user.userprincipalname".
  2. Otherwise find source attribute that contains SAP username. Ex. sAMAccountName. For this scenario choose "Name identifier format" = "Unspecified".

Save and return to "Single sign-on" tab of your Enterprise App configuration. In "SAML Certificates" section download the certificate and federation metadata.

Go back to SAP backend and open T-Code SAML2. Switch to "Trusted Providers" tab and select "OAuth 2.0 Identity providers" under the "List of Trusted providers". Add a new provider using the metadata you just downloaded from EntraID.

In the next step, upload the certificate downloaded from EntraID. In the "Provider" and "Signature and Encryption" steps, click "Next" and then "Finish".

Edit the new trusted IDP and select the name format "Unspecified" or "E-mail", depending on the user mapping scenario. Scenario 1 is "E-mail", scenario 2 is "Unspecified".

Set the "User ID Mapping Mode" according to the scenario. For scenario 1 "email" or "Logon ID" for scenario 2.

Save and enable the configuration.

Open EntraID again and create new App registration (not Enterprise app) that will be used as client.

On "Authentication" tab, section "Platform configurations" click "Add a platform" and select "Web". Set "Redirect URIs" = "https://localhost:44326/signin-oidc" and select both tokens to be issued.

On "Certificates & secrets" tab generate new client secrete. Save the content of "Value" field as you can't access it later!

Next, on "API permissions" tab add a permission "Microsoft Graph" as delegated. Select "openid" (Sign users in).

On "Expose and API" tab add a scope. URI should be predefined. After clicking "Save" new configuration panel will be shown. Fill there "Scope name" = "user_impersonation" and switch consent to "Admins and users". Set some display name and description. Finally click "Add scope".

On the same tab add a client application. Set "Client ID" = "6bee4d13-fd19-43de-b82c-4b6401d174c3" and set our scope in "Authorized scopes". This fixed client ID is identifier of SAP OData connector in PowerApps platform.

Copy "Application (client) ID" from "Overview" tab.

Now switch to App registration (not Enterprise app) that corresponds to the server part (same name as our Enterprise app defined in the beginning). Go to "Expose and API" tab and add a client application. Add there copied client ID and set scope.

One again switch to SAP system. Create technical user for impersonation. This user must be type B (System) and has correct permission role assigned. You need these permissions:

  • S_RFC: RFC_TYPE=Function group, RFC_NAME=SYST, ACTVT=Execute
  • S_SCOPE: OA2_CLIENT=SOAUTH2 (set same as ID of technical user), OA2_SCOPE=<required_scopes> (start with "*" for testing and restrict later)

Call T-Code SOAUTH2. On the screen click "Create". Set ID of technical user as "OAuth 2.0 Client ID" and write some description.

In "Grant Type Setting" step select our trusted IDP from the list and set "Refresh Allowed".

In "Scope Assignment" step set some service that you'd like to expose.

Postman test

It's time for first test. You could use attached Postman collection. Edit variables of the collection.

Variable

Content

Example

SAP GW IP Address

Address of SAP AS

vhigyi4aci.*************

SAP GW Port

Https port of SAP AS

44300

AAD tenant ID

Entra tenant ID (visible on app registration overview)

d3f10f6d-****************

AAD Application ID for SAP GW

SAP AS SAML local provider name

http://I4A400

Frontend App Client Id

Client ID of client app registration

b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f

Frontend App Client Secret

Generated client secret of client app registration

HZ48Q~NDBD38a4XW~************

Frontend App custom scope

Exposed API scope of client app registration

api://b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f/user_impersonation

SAP OAuth Client ID

SAP AS technical user ID

SOAUTH2

SAP OAuth Client Pwd

SAP AS technical user password

krnsW)************

SAP OAuth Scope

Scope (service) defined in OAuth config on SAP AS

ZAPI_BUSINESS_PARTNER_0001

SAPBearerToken

Leave blank, generated in process

 

bearerToken

Leave blank, generated in process

 

Please also change service name and parameters in request number 4 based on your use case (if not calling BP OData service as in example).

Now open first call of the collection and send request. Ignore output and open console (bottom left corner). Copy whole link (without GET keyword) and paste it in the web browser. After successful EntraID login blank error page will be shown. Go to the address bar and copy content of parameter "access_token". Open request number 2 and paste token to the "assertion" parameter.

After sending request number 2 you should see "access_token" in the output. Open request number 3 and send it. If successfull you would get new (short) "access_token" and also "refresh_token" and correct "scope".

Finally open and send request number 4. You should see data from your service.

SAP Integration Suite setup

In order to use this setup from internet / public cloud you have to expose SAP AS over SAP Cloud Connector.

In case that you don't have SAP Integration Suite BTP subaccount already added in SAP Cloud Connector, please use official guide to add it: SAP Help Portal | SAP Online Help

Now go to the Cloud Connector subaccount and select "Cloud to On-Premises" in the left menu. On "Access Control" tab add new system (Mapping Virtual to Internal System). Backend type is "ABAP System", protocol "HTTPS". Fill in hostname and port of SAP AS.

Use same values for virtual host and port. Disable Principal Propagation and Certificate Logon as you don't need these in this scenario. Host in request header should be Virtual Host. Set SID (ex. I4A) as System ID.

Expose services (your OData) in "Resources" section. On this example I'm exposing whole system (don't do this with productive SAP AS!).

Open SAP Integration Suite and begin with setup there. In left menu select Configure -> APIs and select "API Providers" tab.

Create new provider. Fill some meaningful name on "Overview" tab. Switch to "Connection" tab and set "Type" = "On Premise", "Host" = <AS_ABAP_HOST>, "Port" = <AS_ABAP_PORT>, leave "Authentication" = "None". Set "sap-client" = <AS_ABAP_CLIENT> in Additional Properties.

Save provider and test connection. It should return "System is up and reachable. However, the ping check responded with code : 404; Message : Not found". That's correct state because we're calling base URL and not any reachable service.

Go to "Policy Templates" tab and import definition that's available in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This policy needs some mapping. So switch to "Key Value Maps" tab and create new mapping (ex. name "I4ACLNT400_EntraID"). Use table bellow as an example.

Key

Content

Example value

issuer

Standard Microsoft issuer value (constant)

https://sts.windows.net/d3f10f6d-4a4d-4cde-acb6-284a54d78b3a/

AADSAPResource

SAP AS SAML local provider name

http://I4A400

entra-id-audience

Exposed API scope of client app registration (without scope name)

api://b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f

AADRegisteredAppClientSecret

Generated client secret of client app registration

HZ48Q~NDBD38a4XW~************

sap-oauth-client-password

SAP AS technical user password

krnsW)************

AADRegisteredAppClientId

Client ID of client app registration

b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f

SAPOAuthServerAdressForTokenEndpoint

SAP AS host + port

vhigyi4aci.**********:44300

sap-oauth-client-username

SAP AS technical user ID

SOAUTH2

sap-oauth-scope

Scope (service) defined in OAuth config on SAP AS

ZAPI_BUSINESS_PARTNER_0001

entra-id-tenant-id

Entra tenant ID (visible on app registration overview)

d3f10f6d-*****************

Finally switch to "API Proxies" tab and create new proxy. Select your API Provider, set URL to OData service that you have in the scope. Define some name and title of proxy. API Base Path could be anything you like - it's simply prefix for OData calls to this service (ex. /sap/utility/odata).

Ignore error "Unable to fetch metadata" - it's normal as we didn't applied policy yet.

In the new API provider click "..." in top right corner and select "Policies". Again in top right corner click "Policy Template" -> "Apply". Select policy that you downloaded earlier and apply it. You should now see it under target endpoint's post flow.

Now go step by step through the policy. In second step (MapVariables) replace value of "mapIdentifier" with the name of your value map (ex. I4ACLNT400_EntraID). In steps "RefreshSAPToken", "fetchSAPOAuthToken" and "GetCSRFToken" change value of tag "APIProvider" from "PM1-via-SCC" to your provider name (ex. I4ACLNT400_NOAUTH).

Click "Update", "Save" and "Deploy".

Microsoft PowerPlatform test

Login to Microsoft PowerApps at Power Apps and switch to correct environment (if using more). In the left menu click "Flows" and create new cloud flow "Instant cloud flow". Fill some name and choose "Manually trigger a flow".

Add new step with connector "SAP OData", action "Read OData entity".

Set authentication type "Microsoft Entra ID Integrated (with APIM)". OData base URI is URL of you API Proxy service (ex. https://******.test.apimanagement.******.hana.ondemand.com/sap/utility/odata/BusinessPartner), Entra ID resource URI is API scope of client app (ex. api://b20e44f0-d88a-4558-8a53-b34484425e3f/user_impersonation). Set "API Key Name" = "APIKey (constant), "API Key Value" = <Client_secret> (ex. HZ48Q~NDBD38a4XW~************) and SAP's client name / password.

You should see Entra ID popup for login. After that service should be authenticated and entities readable.

Troubleshooting

In case you're struggling with the basic setup (Postman testing), start T-Code SEC_DIAG_TOOL_VIEWER and capture the login traffic. You can find errors there and search SAP for Me. Always double check that user calling API (your business user, not SOAUTH2) is valid and has correct permission assigned (check SU53 for errors).

If calling OData API from PowerApps fails immediately with authentication error, check EntraID tenant log for errors associated with your registered client app.

Sometimes it fails later in login process and this could be debuged on Integration Suite. Open definition of your API Proxy, click "Debug" (top right corner) and "Start Debug" (bottom right corner). Now call API from PowerApps, refresh debugged window and check for errors.

entry.title: Production Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MPS Planning Results [Part 2]
entry.content:
[Blog Type: Hands-on Expertise]

[Blog Series: In the previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results [Part 1], the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor focused on MRP products (purchasing product and intermediate product) was illustrated, while on this blog post the MPS Production Planning Monitor focused on MPS products (final product) is explained.]

 

Summary

This blog post describes how to build a planning monitoring tool to evaluate and manage the MPS results for multiple materials. This tool can show per material the historical consumption data – consumption-based planning – together with the stocks and requirements information – material requirements planning –, and the corresponding MRP created receipt elements to cover the shortages.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the visualization of the MRP results.

 

Introduction

A typical customer requirement is to visualize the result of the MRP run for several materials in a report format, that is, they want MD04 for every material on a plant in a single screen. The purpose is to have an easy and fast way of identification of critical materials where the planner needs to take an action, and then being able to select the specific material and drill down into the stock, requirements and planning elements details. There is not a standard report available that would show a detailed display of stock/requirements list for multiple materials.

A collective MRP results view is normally something very difficult to build, as companies have thousands of materials per plant with different business cases concerning procurement types, planning strategies, production types, origin of the requirements, etc… Furthermore, the target information to be displayed is different depending on the user role:

  • As a production supervisor, buyer, sales executive or MRP controller, you want to access information on the stock/requirements situation of the material, and then gain an overview of the development of stock and requirements in the coming weeks.
  • As a production supervisor, you want to gain an overview of the MRP elements for in-house production (planned orders, production orders, dependent reservations) or of the MRP elements for a particular production line.
  • As a buyer, you want to check which purchase orders and purchase requisitions exist for a material for a particular vendor.
  • As a sales executive, you are only interested in the current sales orders for a particular customer for a material.
  • As an MRP controller, you are interested in available quantities based on sales orders that have actually been received and not on the basis of the planned independent requirements. You therefore want the planned independent requirements to be displayed, but do not want to change the available quantity if sales order exists.
  • As an MRP controller, you want to be informed about the requirements of bulk materials or materials that are planned using consumption-based planning, to check whether these requirements occur continually.

Another issue to consider is the requirement of some customers to manage historical consumption data together with the requirements information, thus allowing them to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same periods in the same single screen.

Therefore, having all these requirements and conditions in mind, we may think that building a collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials becomes a great challenge. This blog explains how this collective planning tool can be built for isolated and specific planning scenarios.

 

Evaluating the Planning Run on SAP S/4HANA

For Classic MRP, the available tools for checking the planning results are the following:

  • Stock/Requirements List
  • MRP List
  • Evaluation of the Planning Situation
  • Evaluation of the Planning Result
  • Planning Table for repetitive manufacturing

During the planning run, the system analyzes the requirements that exist for the planned materials and creates procurement or manufacturing elements to cover these requirements. The evaluations on these tools show all receipt and issue elements for a material in tabular form and enable you to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements situation for the material as well as to branch into the processing function for the MRP elements for this material.

In the stock/requirements list, the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation is displayed. Changes that are made after the planning date are displayed directly, so the list is dynamic. The MRP list always displays the stock/requirements situation at the time of the last planning run. Changes that are made after the planning date are not taken into consideration, so the list is static.

The planning situation takes all changes in stock, receipts and issues that occur between planning runs into account (as in the stock/requirements list). The planning result displays the result of the last planning run (as in the MRP list). The main difference is that you set up a special evaluation layout for the formatting of the data in the planning result and planning situation. This layout defines which receipt and issue elements are displayed at which level of aggregation.

In SAP S/4HANA, the MRP Live is used, and we also have the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps and the MPR Situation Handling. MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live due to the considerable performance improvement. The several available MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps display an overview of materials with possible stock shortages, and you can also drill down into a specific material to see the stock/requirements situation.

The new Fiori Apps for MRP evaluation are more visually appealing, and they contain features only available in Fiori, such as Demand-Driven MRP (DDMRP) and Predictive MRP (pMRP). Moreover, they are also supported in mobile devices.

On below table you can find a summary of the abovementioned MRP transactions or Fiori Apps:

Application

Description

Transaction MD04

Display Individual Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD07

Display Collective Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD05

Individual Display of MRP List

Transaction MD06

Collective Display of MRP List

Transaction MD44

Planning Situation

Transaction MD47

Collective Display for Planning Situation

Transaction MD45

Planning Result

Transaction MD46

Collective Display for Planning Result

Transaction MD48

Multi-Plant Planning Situation

Fiori App F0251A

Manage Material Coverage

Fiori App F2101A

Monitor Material Coverage

 

Customer Requirement for a Collective Evaluation of the MRP Planning Results

Customer business case was a small-sized food company with mainly a mass production environment using discrete manufacturing. Main finished products were fresh products sent to retailers to be sold on the supermarket’s shelf. Therefore, demand was seasonal but also with a special focus on daily consumption pattern.  The customer was interested on running the MRP with requirements based on forecast demand, but also considering the historical consumption of the last four weeks per day, to have the whole picture.

Since it was just a small company, there were only two main MRP responsible for the whole of the planning process and availability control for purchasing products, intermediate production and final product production. The two main areas of responsibility were MPS products, covering the final products to sale, and MRP products, covering the products for purchasing and intermediate production. On this blog we will focus on the MPS products; the MRP products were already covered on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

The customer used a make-to-stock production (goods sold from stock) because of the following reasons:

  • The materials were produced independently of the sales orders.
  • The materials were not assigned to specific sales orders (not segregated).
  • Costs were required to be tracked at material level, and not at sales order level.

The main objective was to quickly provide the clients with goods from the stock. The main constraint was that real sales orders were often received from clients only for one day, and normally with just one day in advance or even the same day. Therefore, customer needed to produce goods without having the sales orders, as expecting the clients demand in future.

On this make-to-stock scenario, to avoid unreasonably high stock levels, a production plan is created in advance, and then you decide whether sales orders exceeding your plan are to affect production or not. Receiving sales orders as early as possible (using scheduling agreements, for example) also contributes to minimize high stock levels, but it was unrealistic on this customer, so a smooth demand forecast was key.

The production was determined by a production plan based on demand forecast (demand management), and only sales orders for first day exceeding the plan directly influenced production. If available, sales order information for subsequent days was required to be displayed for information purposes only (as normally info was uncompleted), but forecast was the demand driver except for the first day. Therefore, planning strategy used was net requirements planning on plant level (strategy 10), which allows to smooth the demand program.

Other very important considerations of the customer for achieving an effective materials planning were the following:

  • Customer wanted to expedite material planning with a more detailed collective material overview than the one provided by standard SAP S/4HANA MRP apps.
  • Customer requested to analyze materials on a dynamic periodic basis, mainly daily, but also weekly and monthly. The operative planning is usually managed by day, meanwhile medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.
  • Customer requested a calculation of stock coverage for every period displayed.
  • Customer worked with two planning modes: the real-time mode, like MD04 with the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation, and the fix-photo mode, similar to MD05 (MRP-List) with a snapshot at the beginning of the day with the situation of initial stock, requirements and receipts.
  • Customer did not plan materials at MRP areas level.
  • Customer needed a more flexible material selection by using the typical grouping fields available on material master.
  • Customer needed a flexible visualization of quantities in several units of measure.

Customer requirement for MRP monitoring was to build a new collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. On this tool, future requirements would be displayed together with historical data, thus allowing the customer to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period. Initial stock and final stock situation for every period based on total requirements and receipts were also required to be displayed.

Final decision was to create two similar planning monitoring tools: one focused on MPS products, the MPS Production Planning Monitor, and other focused on MRP products, the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor. On this blog post we will focus on the MPS Production Planning Monitor, which is described in detail down below. The MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor was already explained on previous blog post Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results.

Figure 1: Material Scope for MRP Live run with MPS/MRP materials.

 

Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Production Planning Monitor MPS was intended for displaying the stock/requirements/receipts situation for a particular or a series of materials, from the point of view of final production, that is, the final product to sale. The prerequisite was the MRP Live (operative production plan MPS & MRP) previously executed for the corresponding plant, and this was automatically done daily at night by a background job.

The evaluations on this Monitor display all receipt and issue elements for the materials in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material, as well as to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements for this material. After a normal MPS&MRP run, the planner checks the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the materials, make necessary changes and ensures the availability of the materials for the next days, by creating production orders. The tool also allowed working by fixing the planning elements planned orders, but customer planners used to directly create the production orders.

As planners of this customer were old-school heavy users of SAP systems, this Monitor was developed in form of ALV list by using the BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST function.

 

Selection Screen for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The selection screen of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 2):

Figure 2: Selection Screen of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

The period of time to be considered must be selected using the fields “Date From” and “Date To”. One week is proposed by default.

Requirements/receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type”. The operative planning (short-term planning) is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.

The materials to be shown can be selected by material type, material group, MRP controller, production scheduler, and/or material code.

 

The default “Planning Mode” is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode the entire requirements of the day and the entire production orders are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode only the pending requirements of the day and the pending production orders are shown.

The quantities shown can be displayed on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user.

The total percentage of loss of the materials can be displayed as scrap (internal SAP), but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator “Split Pre-Production”. This is just an option also related to food processing, to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The calculation of stock coverage on periods can be dynamically changed to consider or not the “-Expired stock” and the “+Production”.

Finally, consumption history can be shown together with MRP data, for 1 period only or for 4 periods.

 

Output List for Production Planning Monitor MPS

An example of the output list of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is displayed on below image (Figure 3):

Figure 3: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

This new monitoring tool allows to display at the same time the following data:

  • MPS planning results over sales & forecast (future).
  • Consumption history (past).

The MRP evaluation on this Monitor displays all receipt and issue elements for every material in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material. Moreover, for every period the historical consumption for the material is shown for the fourth previous periods, and also the average. This allows the planner to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period.

Requirements are shown in negative [- quantity] and receipts in positive [+ quantity], in order to ease the coverage understanding. A colour code red-yellow-green is used on field “Stock Final” to easily identify stock breaks.

This new tool also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell.

The explanation of the meaning of the different columns of the new Production Planning Monitor MPS tool is summarized on below image (Figure 4):

Figure 4: Explanation of the Columns of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool.

 

Displaying Options for Production Planning Monitor MPS

Requirements and receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type” on the selection screen. The operative planning is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning is managed by week/month.

Figure 5: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Week.

Figure 6: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool with Period Type by Month.

 

The monitor has an option for avoiding displaying empty lines, thus planner being able to only focus on periods containing data.

Figure 7: Output List of the Production Planning Monitor MPS tool without empty lines.

 

The monitor also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell. The available screens for the data details are the following:

  • With double-click on the initial stock cell of the first period (current period), you navigate to detail stock list.
  • With double-click on the sales orders cell, you navigate to detail sales orders requirements list.
  • With double-click on the sales forecast cell, you navigate to detail sales forecast requirements list.
  • With double-click on any receipts cell (manufacturing orders), you navigate to detail receipts list.
  • With double-click on any consumption cell, you navigate to detail historical consumption list.

Figure 8: Detail Stock List when double-clicking on the initial stock cell of the first period

Figure 9: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Orders cell

Figure 10: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on the Sales Forecast cell

Figure 11: Detail Receipts List with Production Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (internal procurement material)

Figure 12: Detail Historical Consumption List when double-clicking on any consumption cell

 

The production orders can be splitted on daily production and pre-production quantities, by ticking the indicator “Split Pre-Production”. The concept of pre-production is something used on this plant to separate the production surplus of the previous day.

Figure 13: Output List of the Monitor with “Split Pre-Production” option.

 

The monitor has two planning modes: the fix-photo mode and the real-time mode, similar to classic MRP List (static) and Stocks/Requirements List (dynamic). The default planning mode is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode, the entire requirements of the day and the entire receipts (manufacturing) are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode, only the pending requirements of the day and the pending manufacturing orders are shown.

Figure 14: Output List of the Monitor for the different Planning Modes.

Figure 15: Output List with Details for the different Planning Modes.

 

The monitor can display the quantities on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user. This can be done either on the selection screen or directly on the main screen, as well as the planning mode.

Figure 16: Output List of the Monitor showing quantities in different units of measure.

 

Action Buttons for Production Planning Monitor MPS

The Monitor has an action button to create a new production order (transaction CO01). Furthermore, on the different screens with the details list of receipts, when clicking on the production order, the monitor navigates to the corresponding maintenance application (transaction CO02), where the user can directly edit the date and/or the quantity. This considerably improves the number of clicks required to perform those actions compared to use new modes.

Figure 17: Output List of the Monitor with the action button “Create New Production Order”.

 

Helpful Links

Materials Requirements Planning (SAP Help Portal)

Evaluating the Planning Run (SAP Help Portal)

 

[Disclaimer: Written by Juan Ventura (LinkedIn). This blog post is written by the author based on his personal experience while working on customers with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. Opinions and views expressed herein are solely my own. Before implementing any solution, you are advised to always do the analysis and adopt a solution for specific business case only if it suits customer requirements and testing is successful.]

entry.title: Process Purchase Requisition Centrally app Display material description and number
entry.content:
Hello Dear Support Team,

 

When viewing requisitions in the Process Purchase Requisition Centrally Pstandard descriptions and numbers appear together in fields such as material group and material. Below is an example of a material number. Our customer only wants to see the numbers and not the descriptions. This will make it easier for them to run reports when they export the requisitions to Excel. Can you help us resolve this issue?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Process Purchase Requisition Centrally app Display ma...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

Unfortunately, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not provide standard configuration options to separate material numbers from descriptions in the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app. The system displays material information in the combined format "Description (Material Number)" by design.

Current System Behavior: The Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app displays materials and material groups with both descriptions and numbers together in a single field,

Available Workarounds:

Option 1: Export and Post-Process in Excel

  • Export the purchase requisition data to Excel from the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app .
  • Use Excel functions to separate the material number from the description:

Option 2: Use Alternative Apps for Reporting

  • Consider using the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items Centrally app  which may provide different display options
  • The Central Purchase Requisition Item Types app offers analytical views that might better suit your reporting needs

Option 3: Custom Field Enhancement  you may be able to use the Custom Fields and Logic app to create additional fields that could store material numbers separately  However, this would require:

  • Creating custom fields through the Custom Fields tab
  • Using the business context: Central Procurement: Purchase Requisitions (MM_PUR_HUB_PR_ITEM)
  • This approach would need validation to ensure it meets your specific requirements

Technical Limitation: The combined display format is part of the standard SAP Fiori design for material fields across multiple apps. Similar behavior exists in other purchasing applications where material descriptions and numbers are displayed together.

Recommendation: For immediate needs, the Excel post-processing approach would be the most practical solution. For long-term requirements, consider submitting a feature request through the SAP Customer Influence Portal to request separate display options for material numbers and descriptions in the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app

SAP offers an opportunity for SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers to submit improvement requests using this link: Homepage - Customer Influence (sap.com). Customer Influence (CIS) is a platform where customers can suggest features that they would like to see in future SAP HANA releases.

Please refer to the SAP KBA ##2963059 - How to Submit Feature Requests for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Product.

 

Thanks and Regards

SAP SUPPORT

entry.title: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 1
entry.content:
Co-authored by @EvaWang  and Jessica Dewald

 

What's UCB?

Universal Component Breakdown (UCB) offers comprehensive transparency and insights into the cost structures of products, specifically targeting the costs of goods manufactured and sold. This innovation addresses a critical business need, enabling companies to better understand and manage cost factors that influence product profitability and company contribution margins. UCB will continuously replace the existing product costing capability with an innovative and streamlined solution tailored for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 
 
With the initial version of the product cost breakdown you have a solid foundation to obtain those insights. 
The functionalities of UCB will be gradually enhanced in the coming releases. The result will be a fully integrated solution providing cost transparency from planning and procurement to manufacturing and sales across even complex multi-level value chains. 
In the past, controllers had blurry vision when it came to advising the business on product profitability due to aggregation of things like allocated costs. With the new component breakdown types, opportunities to take action come into focus and new questions can be answered with the data to back them up. 

If you’re new to this topic, you’re in the right place to get answers and find further resources on the following questions: 

  • Which functionalities are included with scope item 7NH, and which additional scope items are required? (See sections What’s Covered by Scope Item 7NH and Scope Activation and Dependencies)

  • How is it set up?  (See sections Scope Activation and Dependencies and SAP Standard Content)
  • What’s the default content and what can you do in terms of configuration? (See section SAP Standard Content)
  • How does it work in an end-to-end scenario? (See part 2 of our blog series)
  • What’s the relationship between UCB and the existing cost component split solution (based on scope item BEG)? (See part 2 of this blog series) 

The UCB solution is currently represented by two scope items. Each of them has a different focus area:  

  • 7NH: Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow
  • 6VN: Product-Related Carbon Emission Quantities

In the following section, we'll focus on the product cost breakdown (7NH).

 

What’s Covered by Scope Item 7NH: Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow

In this blog, we will give you an overview of the key benefits of scope item 7NH (Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow) and will also highlight the new features that have been released with S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition 2508.  

First of all, scope item 7NH enables the production cost breakdown and origin cost breakdown in the plan and actual value flow for a manufactured product with quantity structure and calculates material standard cost estimates.  

Now let’s take a look at what these breakdown types include: 

  • The production cost breakdown provides an explanation of the cost of goods manufactured (COGM) from the point of view of the manufacturing process (material usage, internal activities, external activities, etc.). 
  • The origin cost breakdown is an alternative way of showing the cost of goods manufactured of a product.  You can review the original production factors to understand the impact of changes to your primary costs. These changes include increases in energy prices, higher wage costs, or adjustments in depreciation rules. Without the origin cost breakdown, these costs would be subsumed in the activity rate and simply grouped as production activity costs. 
  • Both the cost of goods manufactured (COGM) breakdown and the cost of goods sold (COGS) breakdown are specific views that you can display for a sold product. They can either be based on the origin cost breakdown or the production cost breakdown structure in product profitability analysis. 

UCB Terminology and Concepts 

You may be familiar with an already existing solution called the “cost component split”, and yes it’s comparable, but UCB offers a lot more. 

To make the new UCB solution more distinguishable from the existing cost component split, we introduced a couple of new terms to describe the key entities of the new breakdown.  

  • UCB method: A component breakdown method is defined by an ID and a method type, which can be either a cost breakdown or a quantity breakdown, and the related component structure.

  • Quantity breakdown structure: The quantity breakdown structure groups quantity components, for example, greenhouse gas (GHG) categories.

  • Cost breakdown structure: The cost breakdown structure groups cost breakdown components and is used to explain, for example, the origin of costs in decision-making.

  • Quantity breakdown component: A quantity breakdown component is an individual element of the quantity breakdown that defines the origin of the quantity in question. For example, downstream transportation or purchased goods and services are possible quantity breakdown components when determining greenhouse gas emission quantities.

  • Cost breakdown component: The cost breakdown component groups G/L accounts that are used to create a detailed analysis of specific expenses associated with a product to gain a more granular insight into resource allocation. Cost breakdown components can be, for example, raw materials or overhead costs.

For more information, see Universal Component Breakdown.

Scope Activation and Dependencies

In order to enable the cost component breakdown, you need to activate scope item 7NH (Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow) in combination with the following mandatory prerequisite scope items: 

  • Integrated Financial Planning (4RC) enables cost rate planning and the cost rate split.

  • Import Connection Setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB) enables the integration of the cost rate breakdown with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It is only required if you want to use the origin cost breakdown. 

For more information on scoping, see SAP Note 3544173.

SAP Standard Content  

You define the cost breakdown structure and their assigned cost components in your configuration environment via the Define Cost Breakdown Structures (ID: 500697) configuration activity. Then, the cost breakdown results are determined automatically through the process of material standard cost estimates and the costs posting from the manufacturing and selling process. 

The following types of cost breakdown structures are available: 

  • Origin Cost Breakdown (OB): It describes the cost breakdown from the point of view of the original costs (for example, material usage with origin group, energy usage, labor usage).

  • Production Cost Breakdown (PB): It describes the cost breakdown from the point of view of the manufacturing process (for example, material usage, internal and external activities).

The production cost breakdown (PB) is the main breakdown structure and is used as the default structure in reporting. The cost of goods sold (COGS) breakdown is based on structures PB and OB. 

Overview of the configuration activity Define Cost Breakdown Structures.

Example of a production cost breakdown structure (PB).

Example of an origin cost breakdown structure (OB).

For more information, see Configuration on the SAP Help Portal. 

Cost Breakdown Hierarchies

In the Manage Global Hierarchies app, you can define your own cost breakdown hierarchies which you can use in reporting. They're based on the configured cost breakdown structures. SAP delivers two default cost breakdown hierarchies:

  • Universal Origin Cost Breakdown Group (UOCB) based on the origin cost breakdown structure.
  • Universal Production Cost Breakdown Group (UPCB) based on the production cost breakdown structure.

 

Predelivered cost breakdown hierarchies in the Manage Global Hierarchies app.

Example of an origin cost breakdown hierarchy.

Cost breakdown hierarchies replace the old cost component group concept. You don't have to define them in your configuration environment any longer. Instead you can maintain them anytime as a business user. 

For more information, see Define Component Breakdown Hierarchies on the SAP Help Portal. 

In the second part of this blog, we will illustrate how UCB works in an end-to-end scenario, first in the plan value flow and then in the actual value flow: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 2 

Related Information

For more information, check out the following pages: 

What’s New (release 2508)

Universal Component Breakdown (UCB) 

Display Cost Rates 

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

SAP Help Portal Documentation:

Universal Component Breakdown 

Cost Component Breakdown 

View Component Breakdown 

Importing Plan Cost Rates from SAP Analytics Cloud 

Configuration 

Define Component Breakdown Hierarchies

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

Display Cost Rates 

SAP Notes: 

3544173 - Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Product Cost Breakdown (Scope Item 7NH) in S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition 

3616085 - Calculation of COGS fixed amounts in app Product Profitability Review Booklet (F8348) 

3408777 - Product-Related Greenhouse Gas Emission Quantities in Product Costing (Scope Item 6VN): FAQ 

Scope Item Descriptions: 

Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow (7NH) 

Integrated Financial Planning (4RC) 

Import Connection Setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB)
